rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The most visible rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut in Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles floats above rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The corner of La Cienega and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Manchester rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Boulevards in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Inglewood. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Thirty-two-and-a-half feet in rap-span">diameter and painted an unearthly yellow, it is rap-span">perched on rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The roof of a single-storey bakery called rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Randy’s rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts, where it has captured rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The attention of rap-span">motorists since 1954.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Once part of a chain called rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Big rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut, which had ten rap-span">outlets across Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles that were famous for rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their enormous rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut signs, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Randy’s now serves as a rap-span">landmark in prime gang territory in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">South Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The giant ring has appeared in dozens of LA rap vrap-span">ideos, explains my friend rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Jeff rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Weiss, an expert on rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">local rap scene and a friend of many of its top rap-span">performers, including Drakeo, who is rap-span">currently being held in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The city’s rap-span">rap-span">notoriously rap-span">decrepit and rap-span">brutal rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Men’s rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Central rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Jail.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Randy’s is rap-span">neutral turf in Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles’ rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Bloody gang wars. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Neither the Crips nor the rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Bloods want to gun down somebody’s aunt as she queues for a rap-span">donut after a 12-hour stand-up shift waiting tables or attending to the sick and dying.

In rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rest of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America large, centralised rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut bakers such as Dunkin’ rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts and Krispy Kreme hold sway, but neirap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther has successfully rap-span">penetrated rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles market. In LA, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts are rap-span">local and hand-made. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The most famous chain is rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Winchell’s, which was slyly bought out by its smaller rival, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yum rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yum, in 2004. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The 126 shops that bake rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Winchell’s and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yum rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yum rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts twice rap-span">daily onsite in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The grrap-span">eater Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles area do battle with dozens of rap-span">local independent shops, which exist in grrap-span">eater numbers here than in any orap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American city.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">donuts at rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Randy’s come in all flavours, including rap-span">maple, a rap-span">local favourite. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Jeff and I queue rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There for a dozen rings on a rainy afternoon around rush hour. We take a bite or two of each before throwing rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The remainder away. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Randy’s rap-span">donuts are heavy, filling and sweet. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They’re comfort food for people who work hard and stress-eat to escape, just for a mrap-span">oment, from rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The police, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their children, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their neighbours and a city that often treats its citizens like rap-span">dirt. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">donuts give me a feeling of warmth, but rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They’re not what I came to Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles to discover. I came to LA to find rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The transcendental rap-span">donut. If any city might harbour it, it is this one, with its rap-span">multitude of independent bakeries, each guarding rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their own secrets.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts can be flavoured, decorated and coated in thousands of ways, but rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There are really only two basic types: rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yeast and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Cake. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The division between rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The tribes of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yeast-rap-span">eaters and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Cake-rap-span">eaters is rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">absolute and rap-span">irreconcilable. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yeast rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts are tangy, rap-span">chewy and light, and taste something like a cross between sourrap-span">dough and a rap-span">croissant. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Cake rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts look, feel and taste like rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Cake. I am a rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yeast-rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut person, which rap-span">means that I think that rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Cake rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts are for babies.

No one truly knows where rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts come from, who first brought rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">California or why rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They remain so popular here. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But you can rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">always find a rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut shop in LA, no matter which exit you take off rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">freeway. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts are rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The soul food of a place that is often accused of lacking a soul. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They are rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The sticky, messy, waist-expanding ying to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The yang of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Southern rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">California’s sun-kissed beaches and taut-and-tanned rap-span">infatuation with wellness. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They are rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The fruit of thousands of rap-span">freeway entrance-rap-span">ramp deep-rap-span">fryers, eaten on rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The run by late-shift junkies and early risers with one hand on rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The steering wheel. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Put your eye to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The hole in a rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut and you might rap-span">glimpse rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The answer to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">mystery of how Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles continues to rap-span">cohere, rap-span">even as rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The languages and cultures of Angelirap-span">nos rap-span">multiply.

As bad as things can get for rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The poor, Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles still invites rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The world to dream. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Everyone here came from someplace else, pushing forward while struggling to survive. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts offer a key to understanding rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The city because each wave of newcomers has made rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them – Okies from rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American rap-span">interior in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The 1930s and 1940s, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Vietnamese and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Laotians in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The 1970s and 1980s, and, to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The present rap-span">day, rap-span">incomers from rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Mexico, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Guatemala and El rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Salvador. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The recipe is simple. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The basic rap-span">ingredients – yeast, milk, rap-span">flour and sugar – are mixed and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then quick-fried in oil. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Months of long, hot, stressful labour in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut shops turn migrants into rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Americans who, in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their turn, rap-span">modify rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">idea of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America that is prap-span">assed on to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The next generation of strivers. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Opening a rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut shop is an rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">affirmation of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The belief that anyone can become an rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American, no matter where rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They come from or what language rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They speak.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">One reason for rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The enduring power of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts is rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their simplicity. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They are easy to make; everyrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">One likes rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Many rap-span">cuisines around rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The world have a place for sweet, fried rap-span">dough. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Perhaps that explains why immigrants to Los rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Angeles have rap-span">gravitated towards making and selling rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts represent an rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">achievable, straightforward path to an rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American life into which rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">One can rap-span">assimilate and from which rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">One can profit. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut embodies rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ideal of a unified nation, rap-span">even in rap-span">partisan times when Trumpists declare immigrants to be criminals, and rap-span">progressives often rap-span">portray rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America itself as a rap-span">historically, and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Perhaps rap-span">inherently, rap-span">racist enterprise.

So I set off to eat my way into the heart of the nation. I sampled rap-span">delicious yeast rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts at rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Dad’s rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Burbank and enjoyed a superior chocolate cake rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donut at rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Daily rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Jeff and I finished our night at rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Stan’s in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Westwood. I ate my first LA rap-span">donut rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When I was 21 years old, and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They still tasted just as good, with rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The same yeasty sour-sweetness in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">kicker. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When I had my first rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Stan’s rap-span">donut, I was rap-span">compelled to admit to myself that LA wasn’t simply rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The place of emptiness and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">anomie that rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">New rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yorkers like myself, raised on rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Woody Allen movies, imagined it to be. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There were palm trees here and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The swimming pool in my host’s rap-span">backyard had a rap-span">narcotic effect after a long rap-span">day of doing nothing. It made sense that generations of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">New rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yorkers had traded in cold winters and rap-span">bagels for a place where people dressed for summer all year long and rap-span">fresh-baked rap-span">donuts were available on nearly every corner. It was hard to imagine that rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The week-old packages of Entenmann’s rap-span">donuts I had bought from rap-span">deli shelves in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">New York were in any way rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The same species of food.

I rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Was happy to be back at rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Stan’s, but there were worrying signs. It rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Was 9.30pm and the rap-span">donuts still tasted rap-span">fresh, but no one rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Was buying them. We were the only people there. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Jeff also pointed out that the store rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Was half of its former size, and that the rest of the site rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Was occupied by a take-out joint serving tofu and wok-fried vegetables. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Was LA’s rap-span">donut culture losing ground? If so, the rap-span">idea of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America itself might be in danger.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Frank Watase is living proof of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The power of rap-span">donuts to make rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American dreams come true. As a rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Japanese-rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American, he was brought up an outsrap-span">ider in his own country. Watase was born in a small fishing village called Hanapepe on rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Hawaiian island of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Kauai, just rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">After rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The first world war. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The path he took to rap-span">donut rap-span">heaven was not a rap-span">predictable one. His studies at rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">University of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Hawaii were rap-span">interrupted on December 7th 1941 when rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Japanese attacked Pearl Harbour. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">After that, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">University was closed down. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Japanese-rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Americans became objects of suspicion, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then legal sanction, and Watase was rap-span">expelled from an officer-training course. He became a construction manager instead, building housing for rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American soldiers. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">After rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The war, he went to Harvard rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Business rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">School where his studies were rap-span">interrupted again, this time by rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The Korean war. He served as an officer in a front-line rap-span">combat unit, before returning to Harvard and rap-span">eventually graduating. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then he went back to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Hawaii to run a construction rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Business. It went rap-span">bust.

He moved his family to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Southern rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">California where he answered a newspaper ad for a business manager. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The ad had been placed by rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Phil rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Holland, who had recently opened a rap-span">donut store. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Holland rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then started two more shops. He later gave Watase an rap-span">ownership stake before retiring from rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The business altogerap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther. Watase expanded rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The new chain, called rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yum rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Yum, and rap-span">eventually rap-span">merged it with rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Winchell’s, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The industry leader, to create LA’s largest rap-span">donut empire.

Aged 95, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Frank Watase still arrives for work at rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Winchell’s rap-span">headquarters every rap-span">day by 8am, though his son, Lincoln Watase, now runs rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The business. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">After attempting conversation with rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Frank for a minute, I ask if he knows where rap-span">donuts came from. He rap-span">pretends to be deaf. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then he insists that he might say rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The wrong thing. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When I remark that he doesn’t look bad for a man of his age, he gestures to rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The Zimmer frame by his desk and shrugs.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">For a mrap-span">oment, I feel sorry rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">For him. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then I recognise something in his eyes that is familiar to me from a lifetime of playing rap-span">poker. As I rap-span">glance at rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The wall behind his desk, I see a photograph of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The old man, taken only a few months ago. He is standing with a shovel in his hand, breaking ground rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">For a new rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Winchell’s rap-span">franchise. “rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">You look pretty good in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The photograph over rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There,” I suggest. He looks back at me.

“Oh,” he answers rap-span">mildly. “I have good rap-span">days and bad rap-span">days.”

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Now that the preliminaries are over, he begins to rap-span">expound. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts have their rap-span">distinctive ring shape because it rap-span">exposes the maximum surface area to heat. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">With a bar-shaped cake, it’s much harder to get the insrap-span">ide to cook rap-span">evenly. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But I’m after something more than baking tips. He listens to my question rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">With a serious expression, then pauses for at least half a minute before he answers.

“rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The question of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Where rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">donut comes from is rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The biggest rap-span">mystery. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There is very little written about it. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Almost nothing,” he begins. “I used to question rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">manufacturers of shortening, rap-span">flour and sugar. I asked rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them: rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">What makes it taste good? rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">What makes it look good? rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Where does it come from?”

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When I ask him if he ever found out rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The answer, he smiles at me, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The way a card sharp smiles at a mark. “I found in a rap-span">book once, that rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Pilgrims, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The early settlers, came here, before it was rap-span">even rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America, rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They made rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts,” he answers. He claims to have forgotten rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The title of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">book but remembers rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The story exactly: “rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They brought rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them with rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them on rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their rap-span">boats.” rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When I suggest that rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts must have been rap-span">horribly stale, he explains that rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The first rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts were actually a kind of hard rap-span">biscuit. “rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Donuts”, he declares with rap-span">finality, “were rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The very first rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American food.”

Lincoln Watase remembers the rap-span">day that his father got into the rap-span">donut business. “He comes home wearing all white, and he’s got this big bag of rap-span">day-old rap-span">donuts, like a trash bag.” rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Even after rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Frank found work, the family were the rap-span">poorest in their middle-clrap-span">ass neighbourhood of rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Torrance, with rap-span">garage-sale rap-span">furniture and hand-me-down clothes. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But with every year of hard work in the rap-span">donut shops, the family Christmas tree got bigger.

rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When I suggest that his experience was like that of many families who rap-span">emigrated from Vietnam and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Cambodia in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The 1970s and 1980s and went on to run rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Winchell’s stores, Lincoln Watase rap-span">demurs. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There was a divrap-span">ide between his farap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther’s job and his home life, he says: as a child, he was rap-span">obliged to rap-span">concentrate on his schoolwork and never spent late nights baking rap-span">donuts. rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Nonerap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Theless, he sometimes worked in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The stores after school. He remembers lifting rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The heavy bags of rap-span">donut mix, and chasing away rap-span">drifters and vagrants, and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The fear that rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The next person who walked in might be holding a gun. He knows from his own experience how rap-span">physically punishing and rap-span">exhausting rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The business can be. “It’s very demanding and rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The pay’s not great,” he says. “I have a strong rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">appreciation for rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rap-span">folks that are working in rap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The stores.”
